climbs.name: Unfinished Business
climbs.fa: December 5, 2021  Alex Hill, Alex Wodarczk, Jim Borton

content.description: Start under the big overhang with a finger crack at the water's edge.  Climb the obvious line overhead.  This is the crux.  Protect with small cams.  The belayer may wish to build an anchor slightly to the right, out of the fall line.  Look for two solid cam placements down low. If the leader pops, you’ll avoid a dunking. Climb to the ledge directly above and finish on Cicadas in Your Pants.
content.location: Located at the far left of the cliff at the water's edge.

content.description: Project the first moves with a hex (#8?).  Or be creative with something else.  Pull up high enough to get get your feet on small foot holds to the left and right of the crack.  The reach up and left for a nice but dirty (as of 8/7/2021) horizontal and plug in a bomber #3 Camalot.  Move up and right across the slab.  Look for pro in the leaves and dirt.  It's there.  Aim for the big overhang.  As you step from the slab on the face look right for a great placement for a very small TCU or something comparable.  Find a nice solid flake overhead and place a small but solid cam.  Move up up and slightly left to placer a larger solid cam before you make the exit moves.Trust but verify.  The flakes are better than they look.
content.protection: Gear to 3 inches.  Cams and a medium hex.
content.location: Begin at the left end of the Main Face closer to the water.  This climb begins on the overhanging short crack to the right of Lulu's Leisure.

content.description: Begin under the large overhang at the bottom of The Prow.  From this cave-like feature you can, if tall-enough, place a bomber #3 Camalot in a horizontal up and left.  This protects the bouldery start, which is the hardest move on the climb.  If instead you walk your feet up and hang off of your arms to place your pro, it's harder. Maybe 5.7.  The move up onto the face is either graceful or ugly depending on how you do it.  Small cams provide pretty good protection on the slab.  Very easy, but don't fall here.  You'll hit the ground.  Not good.  A bigger cam or two offers good pro as you top out.Named after an unfortunate encounter with wildlife.
content.location: Look for the large overhang and slab to the left of The Prow.

content.description:
Follow the obvious crack through the lower bulge (crux 1) and finally through the big roof at the top (crux 2).  Protect the final moves with a red Tricam in an unlikely shallow slot.  This can be backed up with an #1 Camalot.  Drop a stopper in the narrow crack at the lip of the roof.  Then cut loose.

 Named after our canine companion Lulu, who thoroughly chilled out at the crag.  The companion climb to Dane's Delight on The Reservoir Wall.
content.protection: Gear to 4 inches. Cams, nuts, a hex, and a red Tricam.

content.description: Climb the face to the left of the obvious dihedral.  Stay on the right side of the face.
content.protection: TR anchor using trees on the top.

content.description: Start low down on the left side of the Dihedral Wall.  If you begin with your feed in the "cave" at the bottom, the bouldery start is 5.7.  Maybe 5.8 depending on your height.  Avoid the arete on the left as you ascend.  Primarily face climbing.  Needs some cleaning.
content.location: Right side of the Dihedral Wall.

content.description: A classic open book.  Climb the corner straight to the tops.  Overhang to the right is a possibility.  Though rock quality should be evaluated carefully.     Leadable.  Gear looks OK.  Cams.  Tricams.  Some friable rock.  Needs a bit of cleaning.
content.location: To the right of the main wall.  Look for an obvious dihedral capped by a roof.

content.description: Start in the obvious low dihedral on the left of the main face, just above the water.  Sketchy gear.  Small wired nut.  Slightly awkward move to gain the ledge above.  Follow the obvious crack above up the corner.  Your can bail out to your left or continue right at the top to turn the overhang.  Great pro in horizontals just above the overhang.  Nice exposure at the top.First ascent done during the 2021 cicada invasion.  Don't let them crawl up your pants.
content.protection: Gear to 4 inches.  Cams, nuts, tricams.
content.location: Left end of the main face, close to the water.

content.description: In case the Reservoir Wall isn't enough, PBR offers a bonus wall. Same type of rock---schist with tilted bedding. But with vertical and horizontal cracks that eat gear. Beautiful water views.
